"As an illustration of the kind of instruc- tion provided, consider the vocabulary in- struction from The Bremen Town Musicians (Plume, 1998), a story about a series of aban- doned animals who set off to make their musical fortune. The words feast, exhausted, and cautiously were selected from the story. The following explains the way feast was taught. The words in quotations are from the script that teachers received for the in- struction and illustrate how the information was provided to students. • First, the word was contextualized for its role in the story: “In the story, it said that the animals found the robbers’ ta- ble full of good things to eat, and so they had a feast.” • Next, the meaning of the word was ex- plained: “A feast is a big special meal with lots of delicious food.” • The children were asked to repeat the word so that they could create a pho- nological representation of it: “Say the word with me: feast.” • Examples in contexts other than the one used in the story were provided: “People usually have a feast on a hol- iday or to celebrate something special. We all have a feast on Thanksgiving Day.” • Children made judgments about ex- amples: “Which would be a feast: eat- ing an ice cream cone or eating at a big table full of all kinds of food? Why?” • Children were asked to construct their own examples: “If you wanted to eat a feast, what kinds of food would you want?” • The word’s phonological and mean- ing representations were reinforced: “What’s the word that means a big special meal?”"

int_desc_ht: ['Page 60:\n[¬s]"Dialogic Reading (Whitehurst, Falco et al., 1988) is an oral language intervention through which children are encouraged to interact with the storybook. During book reading the teacher or adult asks the children questions, encourages answers and helps the children to develop more sophisticated responses to the text. After a few sessions, children are asked to become more active participants in the book reading experience by becoming the storytellers. Appendix A provides the intervention schedule including the list of titles utilized in this study. The storybooks selected for use in this study were based on the recommendations of the creators of the Dialogic Reading technique (Whitehurst et al., 1994). The following is a description of key components of the Dialogic Reading technique followed by a description of prompts used during reading: Key Components Prompt. The children are prompted to say something about the book or page (for example, "What\'s this? Tell me about this page?). Individual students are called on to offer comments about what \x93story\x94 is being told on a given page. Evaluate. Individual responses are evaluated by the teacher and the child is asked another question that will pinpoint specifics about the text. Expand. When a child offers a response, the teacher adds information to the response so that all the children can hear the details of the story. Repeat. The teacher repeats the child\x92s responses to make sure the other children hear the response. This also gives the child a chance to clarify his/her response if desired.[¬e]"', 'Page 61:\n[¬s]"Completion. This type of prompt is used when the teacher leaves a blank at the end of the sentence in order to let the child predict the final word. This is most often used when working with rhyming material, but can also be used with predictable text. Recall. This type of prompt requires asking questions about what occurred on a specific page or to summarize the main parts of a story. Recall questions can also be asked prior to reading a storybook. Open ended. This type of questioning involves asking students to describe what is happening in a specific picture in the book. This prompt works best with storybooks that contain richly detailed illustration. W prompts. These prompts simply refer to asking what, when, where, why, and how questions. Distancing. For this component, children are asked to relate the pictures or words to their own life experiences. Distancing questions help children with verbal fluency, conversation abilities, and narrative skills (for example, "Tell me about a time you felt afraid").[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 16:\n[¬s]"Dialogic Reading (Whitehurst, Falco et al., 1988), and other similar interventions designed to increase oral language skills in young children, have been found to increase phonological awareness indirectly through increasing oral language ability (Lonigan, 2006). Dialogic Reading is a shared storybook reading activity developed to offer a context for interactive dialogue between an adult and children. This technique encourages active participation by the child in telling and re-telling the story. Language skills are reinforced by asking questions, assisting children with expanding on their responses, and providing specific praise. This technique allows the adult and children to jointly construct meaning from the text while supporting the development of a more sophisticated language system.[¬e]"']
